question: Well, you tell the boys on the board to tell the boys downtown to let the boys in Washington know that the press has been nosing around my people in the front office.
answer: You handle your front office people, I'll handle the press and leave the boys in Washington to the boys downtown and the boys downtown to the boys on the board.

question: Commissioner.
answer: What?

question: Here. For the best little computer officer on the Mercury mission.
answer: Simon.

question: Who would believe that Elaine Thompson was once a stewardess on the Denver-Chicago run.
answer: And I can hardly believe that I'm engaged to someone like you, Simon. I'm a very lucky woman.

question: Women and the space program have come a long way, sweetheart. But after the wedding, no more complicated computers for my little girl.
answer: But, darling, they've offered me a chance to head up the computer analysis division for the Jupiter probe.

question: Is that your puppy, son?
answer: Yeah, his name is Scraps and he's going to Mercury with us.

question: No dogs are allowed on the shuttle, son.
answer: But they said...

question: Scraps will have to be shot. I can do it for you here if you like.
answer: Scraps!!!

question: There's no way this wiring could have passed inspection without Simon Kurtz's okay!
answer: Just patch up the damage and get that ship ready to fly. That's an order, mister!

question: You've got it, mister. But you can tell your boys on the board for me that this thing stinks to high heaven of kickback.
answer: You heard it, boys. Now, what do you say?

question: You folks need any help?
answer: Thanks, but we have a terrific woman in on Thursdays.

question: Say, isn't that Dr. Barrington, the world- renowned agronomist?
answer: Yes.

question: It's a privilege to meet you, sir, I'm familiar with all your work.
answer: Let's go, Daddy. We have to check in. He was never appreciated at the Institute.

question: Ah, yes, the Institute, I'm familiar with it.
answer: Now he's D-Y-I-N-Ging and wants to be buried on Mercury.

question: No, I've been excited before.
answer: Elaine.

question: Te...!
answer: That's not important now, Elaine. We have to talk.

question: Ted, we've been worried sick ever since you escaped from the Ronald Reagan Institute For The Mentally Feeble.
answer: Are you on the Mercury mission?

question: You won't get away with this, Simon!
answer: Ted, what's wrong?

question: Ask Simon.
answer: Ted, you're overworked. You've been flying yourself into the ground.

question: There's nothing wrong with me!
answer: Let's relax tonight, just the two of us. I'll make a quiet Italian dinner just the way you like it, with spaghetti.

question: You're as bad as the rest of them, Elaine! It's all here in the design specifications! Look! It's all here!
answer: No! Wait! You're hurting him!

question: I'm perfectly sane.
answer: Excuse me, are you alright? I noticed you talking to yourself. I'm a nurse. Can I be of some help?

question: Uh... oh, thank you. It's nothing.
answer: You don't have to thank me, I'm a nurse. This is my father, Dr. Barrington.

question: Not Dr. Barrington, the world renowned agronomist?
answer: Yes. He's dying a-n-d wants to be buried on Mercury.

question: I'm familiar with your work, Doctor. You'll have to excuse me, I have to go.
answer: You don't have to excuse yourself. I'm a nurse. I understand.

question: Don't be too long.
answer: Elaine.

question: Ted, please. You're just making things difficult for yourself.
answer: Elaine, what happened to us?

question: His name's David Stockman. He's been here twenty years, that's all he says.
answer: Ted, you must remember what the doctor said, the first step on the road to sanity is admitting that you're sick. Now take your electro-shock and you'll be back at the space center in no time. And by the way, Ted, I'm leaving you for Simon. I just can't go on living with a man who refuses to deal with reality, Ted. I have to go now. Believe me, it's best for all concerned.

question: No goodbyes, Elaine. Just go.
answer: If that's the way you want it.

question: That's the way I want it. Just turn the radio on and go.
answer: Goodbye, Ted. I don't want to hurt you.

question: That's right, Commissioner. Senselessly murdered just minutes ago.
answer: That just doesn't make any sense.

question: I wonder how your boys in Washington are going to take this one.
answer: I told you, leave the boys in Washington to the boys downtown and the boys down...

question: I have to see Bud Kruger.
answer: Do you have an appointment, sir?

question: No, dammit. It's a matter of life or death.
answer: You'll have to be more specific than that, sir.

question: All right, it's a matter of death.
answer: Death, death. How about the first Thursday in March, ten o'clock. You can't go in there!

question: Don't try to stop me!
answer: But that's not a door. The door's over there.

question: Take this, Joey. It's my last few bucks. You'll need a hot meal when you get there.
answer: We've spent everything on these operations. Is it really worth it? We've pawned your mother's wedding ring. The kids have no winter clothes...

question: Joey, what's more important, the kids' clothes or your sexual potency.
answer: I don't want to hear that word!

question: Okay, Joey. The Doc says you gotta relax. This hospital in Des Moines is the best sex clinic in the country.
answer: All right. Here.

question: What...? All right. Goodbye, Babe. Joey! Remember, sexual impotence is nothing to be ashamed of!
answer: Time, Newsweek, the Lifesavers, and the second time bomb from the right.

question: Elaine.
answer: Ted! What are you...?

question: I have to get in there. I have to stop this flight.
answer: Ted, we're taking off!

question: Ted seemed to get worse after I told him about Simon, Doctor.
answer: The human brain is a highly complex organ, Elaine, perhaps the most complex next to the bladder. (he stops at a patient in a wheelchair with his back TO So you see, our task isn't made any easier by Ted's refusal to admit that he's sick.

question: What can I do, Doctor Rumack?
answer: You can eat balanced meals, exercise, and take Geritol.

question: I mean for Ted.
answer: You can be gentle with him, Elaine. He's been working out a lot of his aggressions here in the garden.

question: Is that a good sign, Doctor?
answer: It does the job.

question: Hello, Ted. I brought you some spaghetti. What are you doing, Ted?
answer: I've got it, Elaine! I've figured out what's wrong with the shuttle!

question: Ted.
answer: Not now, Elaine!

question: Intermitant failure in scan mode "R". Analyze.
answer: Negative.

question: That doesn't make sense. Repeat analysis.
answer: Negative.

question: That's not possible.
answer: Cut the Doubting Thomas shit, Elaine. I know where I'm coming from on this.

question: Elaine, I'm sorry about that little outburst a moment ago.
answer: That's okay, ROK.

question: Can I say something of a personal nature to you?
answer: Go ahead.

question: You have great tits.
answer: Simon, I'm going to check ROK's secondary readout unit.

question: Yes, Mary?
answer: Would you like a little breakfast, Captain Oveur? Over.

question: A couple eggs and juice would be nice, Mary. Over.
answer: How would you like your eggs, Captain? Over.

question: No. Poached. Over.
answer: Poached and over, Captain Oveur? Over.

question: Just poached on toast. Over.
answer: I don't think we do poached eggs on toast over, Captain Oveur. Over.

question: That's how I want them. Poached. Over.
answer: All right, Captain Oveur. Over.

question: I sure an glad they let Scraps ride up here with us.
answer: I bet Scraps is going to love Mercury.

question: Do you think things will be a lot different on Mercury, Dad?
answer: It's going to be terrific. A whole new world, new kids to play with.

question: No more headlines about the rape trial and the fraud charges?
answer: How many kids get a chance to live on another planet.

question: No more kids yelling, 'Your old man's a thieving rapist'?
answer: Look, a man can make an honest mistake!! Anyway, she was asking for it! They're all asking for it all the time!!

question: Elaine.
answer: Ted. I don't know why you got on this flight. I don't know what you're trying to prove.

question: Elaine, we have to go back.
answer: We can't go back. We had something very special, but it's all over.

question: Elaine, I mean the mission has to be aborted. This ship should never have passed FSA inspection. This thing is held together by string and chewing gum.
answer: Ted, get a grip on yourself. You should never have left the hospital.

question: Then you do think I'm insane.
answer: I've never used the word insane, Ted.

question: What word would you use, Elaine?
answer: The word is sick. Ted -- very, very, very sick.

question: What would you say if I told you the toilet just blew up in my face.
answer: I'd use the word insane.

question: There's something dangerously wrong with this ship, Elaine. I know its the wiring. That toilet's just the tip of the iceberg.
answer: Ted, a toilet's not going to kill anyone.

question: You've been hurt.
answer: I'm getting over it. If a relationship isn't working, you can't force it.

question: No, I mean your head. Sit down. I'll take a look at it. I'm a nurse. Do you want to talk about it.
answer: I opened this panel and a vacuum cleaner hit me.

question: No. I mean your relationship.
answer: We were in love but I'm not sure I know what love is anymore.

question: Love's the same as it always was. It's people who change.
answer: People change in relation to each other. Love changes on its own.

question: Not if the people change together in relation to that love.
answer: Sure. But that's only when the love itself goes unchanged.

question: Then the relationship remains the same and the love changes only when there's change in the two people who share that love.
answer: I just wish it was that simple. We really were in love. You know how it is when you laugh all the time.

question: No. It's hard to L-A-U-G-H when your father's dying.
answer: Well, we laughed. We laughed all the time. We laughed when times were good. Even when times weren't so good, we still laughed. But most of all, we laughed when we felt closest to each other. That's our story.

question: Now what?
answer: That's an asteroid field. There shouldn't be anything like that in this sector unless...

question: Unless?
answer: Unless those sunspots are interfering with our scanner or...

question: Or?
answer: Or we're off course, but...

question: But?
answer: But we couldn't be off course. Our coordinates are computer-locked barring...

question: Barring?
answer: Barring a computer failure. There was talk of sub-par wiring in this ship. I hope that's just talk. Come on up, Jimmy. Say, that's some puppy. What's his name?

question: Barring a computer failure. There was talk of sub-par wiring in this ship. I hope that's just talk. Come on up, Jimmy. Say, that's some puppy. What's his name?
answer: Scraps.

question: Can I hold him?
answer: Sure.

question: He's a boy dog.
answer: Yeah.

question: Request; comprehensive electrical systems check.
answer: Systems check positive. Look, Elaine,

question: Request; life support systems check.
answer: Life support check. Elaine, it's obvious you've been ignoring me. You're a woman. I can relate to that.

question: Request; self-analysis of ROK hardware and software systems regarding behavioral changes.
answer: There's nothing wrong with me, Elaine. What about tonight -- just you and me. We can be alone. I can get rid of everyone else on the ship -- I've already proven that.

question: Did you feel that?
answer: Yes I did...

question: Felt like a large asteroid.
answer: Yes it did. Mr. Dunn, can I ask you a personal question?

question: What is it, Mary?
answer: Um... Do you people scream right when you... you know.

question: I don't think we have any alternative, Captain.
answer: I see. What do you think our alternatives are?

question: We have to disconnect ROK's higher brain functions without disturbing his regulatory system.
answer: Roger.

question: You can do it from up here, Captain.
answer: I'd rather sit down for this one, Elaine.

question: No, I mean you can do it from the cockpit.
answer: Roger. You better get back there and monitor the regulatory unit.

question: Simon, what's happening?!
answer: He tried to disconnect ROK. It gassed him. That computer is running this ship and we're heading right for the sun.

question: Can't we change course?
answer: We're computer locked and the manual navigation unit is down.

question: Then Ted was right!
answer: My career is shot.

question: Striker.
answer: Kurtz, you're drunk. Who's in command of this ship?

question: That damn computer has taken over. I'm getting out.
answer: Then Elaine was right.

question: Don't talk to me about Elaine. Outta my way!
answer: Pull yourself together! We've got to...

question: Ted, I was wrong about you.
answer: We all make mistakes, Elaine.

question: How could I ever have doubted you?
answer: That's all behind us now, Elaine. And no matter what happens, I want you to know I've always loved you.

question: The boys downtown are taking the heat from the boys in Washington and the boys... Bud, the President wants an explanation.
answer: Forget it. I was reading.

question: I was reading too.
answer: What's the story?

question: Some southern plantation owner falls in love with this poor...
answer: I was asking McCrosky, Commissioner. Give it to me straight, McCrosky -- what's it look like. Not the radio, the situation. I want to know exactly what your people think.

question: We're closer to the sun than I estimated.
answer: Come in, Mayflower. This is Bud Kruger. Over.

question: This is Striker.
answer: Look, Striker, I don't know how you got into that driver's seat but I want Simon Kurtz on that radio and I want him now!

question: Which passenger is Joe Salucci?
answer: Sixteen 'C', why?

question: He's carrying a bomb.
answer: A b...

question: No, a bomb. Now, as discreetly as possible, I want you to move the passengers into the lounge.
answer: What should I say?

question: Anything. Just don't let Salucci think we're onto him.
answer: Would everyone not carrying a bomb please move to the lounge.

question: Don't anyone move!
answer: Mr. Salucci, listen to me. Joe, you don't want to blow that thing and kill all these innocent people.

question: I don't want to live anymore.
answer: Joe, the insurance policy won't help your wife and kids. You bought auto insurance, not life insurance.

question: What?
answer: That's right, Joe. Now, no one's going to hurt you and no one has to know what's wrong with you.

question: You're sure?
answer: I'm sure.

question: I've lost the ship and now I've lost you, Elaine. I'm getting out.
answer: Simon, I didn't want it to end like this. We can be friends! You'll die out there.

question: Maybe.
answer: Simon, what are you saying?!

question: I'm saying, I can't take the singles scene again, Elaine.
answer: Simon, no!

question: Simon just ejected!
answer: Sit down, Elaine. If this bomb trick works we just might make it. Simon was a fool to eject now.

question: You mean...
answer: That's right -- premature ejection.

question: What will happen to him, Ted?
answer: The sun will heat that thing to over 450 degrees within seconds. He'll roast like a pig on a spit. Are you afraid?

question: Not when I'm with you, Ted.
answer: I guess you'd have to be a fool not to be afraid at a time like this.

question: We've blown the computer! Elaine! Set course change!
answer: Set!

question: Now!
answer: Compute!

question: Kramer, the WORP control handle just came off in my hand.
answer: Try another handle!

question: There are no more handles, only switches.
answer: No buttons?!

question: Just switches, lights, and knobs.
answer: I'd give my right arm to get just one of these buttons or levers up there right now. Okay, Striker. You're going to have to pull that lever panel off.

question: Screw driver!
answer: Now find a piece of metal and stick it in there.
